column4: Cubic accepts sweetened buyout offer from Veritas Capital, Elliott
column5: (Reuters) - Cubic Corp said on Wednesday it had agreed to a sweetened buyout offer from private equity firm Veritas Capital and U.S. hedge fund Elliott Management that values the defense electronics maker at about $2.38 billion.
column6: The move ends a bidding war for Cubic, which had also attracted a $2.4 billion, or $76 per share, approach from Singapore’s ST Engineering last month.
column7: The latest offer from Veritas and billionaire Paul Singer’s Elliot values the San Diego-based company at $75 per share and is at a discount of 2% to its shares’ last close.
column8: Veritas and Elliot had agreed to take Cubic private in February by paying $70 per share before ST Engineering made a bid.
column9: Cubic said in a statement on Wednesday that it had ceased further engagement with the Singapore-based company.

column4: Cubic Corp receives $2.4 billion buyout offer from Singapore's ST Engineering
column5: (Reuters) - Cubic Corp said on Monday it had received an unsolicited offer from Singapore’s ST Engineering to buy the company for about $2.4 billion, boosting the software maker’s shares to match the offer price of $76.
column6: ST Engineering’s offer is superior to a rival bid by private-equity firm Veritas Capital and U.S. hedge fund Elliott Management, which together agreed to buy Cubic for $2.2 billion, or $70 per share, last month.
column7: Cubic, whose shares rose as much as 9.2%, said its board had decided to engage in discussions with ST Engineering, which makes automatic fare collection machines for metro stations, to evaluate the new offer. Cubic makes revenue management software for the transportation industry.
column8: ST Engineering said Cubic's transportation systems business fits with ST Engineering's strategy to pursue growth in the smart city domain. (bit.ly/3c7D4eA)

column4: Cubic Corp receives $2.4 bln buyout offer from Singapore's ST Engineering
column5: March 22 (Reuters) - Cubic Corp has received an unsolicited offer from Singapore’s ST Engineering to buy the company for about $2.4 billion, the U.S. maker of revenue management software for transportation industry said on Monday.

column4: Cubic to be taken private for $2.2 billion by Veritas, Elliott
column5: (Reuters) - Cubic Corp has agreed to be bought by private equity firm Veritas Capital and U.S. hedge fund Elliott Management in a deal valued at about $2.2 billion, the defense and transportation technology firm said on Monday.
column6: The company had adopted a poison pill last year, allowing existing shareholders to buy more shares at a discount, after Elliott took a 15% stake in the firm with an aim to acquire the company.
column7: The all-cash offer of $70 per share represents a premium of about 11% to Cubic’s closing price on Friday and values the company at about $2.8 billion, including debt.
column8: Cubic makes technology that helps major subway systems collect fares and has also developed a game-based learning technology for the defense industry.
column9: The deal is expected to close during the second quarter of 2021, Cubic said.

column4: Cubic to be taken private in $2.8 billion deal with Veritas, Elliott
column5: Feb 8 (Reuters) - Cubic Corp has agreed to be bought by private equity firm Veritas Capital and U.S. hedge fund Elliott Management in a deal valued at about $2.8 billion, including debt, the defense and transportation technology firm said on Monday. (Reporting by Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru; Editing by Arun Koyyur)

column4: Elliott and Veritas Capital submit offer for Cubic -sources
column5: Sept 22 (Reuters) - Hedge fund Elliott Management and buyout firm Veritas Capital have made a joint bid for Cubic Corp following weeks of private talks with the defense and transportation technology firm, people familiar with the matter said on Tuesday.
column6: The offer is at a premium to Cubic’s closing share price on Tuesday of $54.73, said the sources, who asked to remain anonymous because the matter is private. The exact value of the offer could not be learned. Cubic currently has a market value of $1.7 billion.
column7: Elliott and Cubic declined to comment. A spokesman for Veritas did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
column8: On Monday, Cubic announced it adopted a poison pill after Elliott took a 15% stake in the firm and expressed interest in acquiring the company with a private equity partner. Elliott confirmed its interest in a separate statement without disclosing the name of its partner for the deal.
column9: Elliott is best known for being an activist investor but has branched out into buying companies outright in recent years. The hedge fund and Veritas last partnered in 2018 for a $5.7 billion deal to take healthcare software company Athenahealth private.
column10: Cubic’s shares have slumped this year over fears the coronavirus pandemic may slow the company’s growth in the near term. Cubic makes technology that helps major subway systems collect fares as well technology for the defense industry, areas that are largely dependent on government spending. (Reporting by Rebecca Spalding in New York and Mike Stone in Washington; Editing by Tom Brown)

column4: IN BRIEF: Cubic taps veteran defense lawyer as general counsel
column5: Transportation and defense technology company Cubic Corp said Monday it has hired a lawyer with long-term in-house experience as general counsel.
column6: Hilary Hageman joined San Diego, California-based Cubic as senior vice president, general counsel and corporate secretary, the company said in a statement Monday. She succeeds Jim Edwards, who is retiring after eight years as the company’s top lawyer, it said.
